uk.ac.ebi.utils.threading

Class BatchProcessor<S,B>

  • java.lang.Object
    • uk.ac.ebi.utils.threading.BatchProcessor<S,B>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    SizeBasedBatchProcessor

    public abstract class BatchProcessor<S,B>
extends Object

    A simple class to manage processing of data in multi-thread mode.

    The idea implemented here is that process(Object, Object...) runs a loop where:

    • gets a data item from its input source of type S, for instance S might be a list of records
    • optionally transforms the data item and sends the result to the current batch collector of type B, for instance B might be of type Set<S>
    • invokes handleNewBatch(Object, boolean), which decides if it's time to issue a new batch processing job. For example, the job might save the records in a single transaction. If a new job is actually issued by handleNewBatch(Object, boolean), this also asks getBatchFactory() for a new (eg, empty) batch, and hence the hereby process() method should assign this new batch to the current batch being filled with items from S. For instance, handleNewBatch(Object, boolean) might decide to issue a new job when the current set of records has enough elements and then getBatchFactory() might be used to get a new empty set of records.

    Each invocation of handleNewBatch(Object, boolean) might spawn the creation of a new batch job, via getBatchJob(), which is then submitted to the executor service, and hence the batch processing happens in multi-thread mode.

    After the main loop described above, process(Object, Object...) should invoke waitExecutor(String), to wait for the completion of the that the parallel jobs execution.

    The call to waitExecutor(String) also resets the internal ExecutorService, which will be recreated (once) upon the first invocation of getExecutor(). This behaviour ensures that process(Object, Object...) can be invoked multiple times reusing the same batchJob instance (normally that's not possible for an ExecutorService after its ExecutorService.awaitTermination(long, TimeUnit) method is called).

    You can find a usage example of this class in the rdf-utils-jena package.

    Author:
    brandizi
    Date:
    1 Dec 2017

      Supplier<B> getBatchFactory()
      Every time that handleNewBatch(Object, boolean) decides it’s time to work on a new task and destination D, this supplier is used to generate such new destination.

      • process

      • process

        public void process(S source)

      • handleNewBatch

        protected B handleNewBatch(B currentBatch)

      • handleNewBatch

        protected B handleNewBatch(B currentBatch,
                           boolean forceFlush)

        This is the method that possibly issues a new task, via the getExecutor(), which runs the batchJob against the current destination.

        Note that your task handler will be executed under the default wrapper.

        Parameters:
        forceFlush - if true it flushes the data independently of #getChunkSize().

      • decideNewBatch

        protected abstract boolean decideNewBatch(B batch)

        handleNewBatch(Object, boolean) decides to generate a new task based on the value returned by this.

      • getBatchJob

        public Consumer<B> getBatchJob()

        Every new parallel task that is generated by process(Object) and handleNewBatch(Object, boolean) runs this batchJob.

      • setBatchJob

        public BatchProcessor<S,B> setBatchJob(Consumer<B> batchJob)

      • getBatchFactory

        public Supplier<B> getBatchFactory()

        Every time that handleNewBatch(Object, boolean) decides it’s time to work on a new task and destination D, this supplier is used to generate such new destination.

      • setBatchFactory

        public BatchProcessor<S,B> setBatchFactory(Supplier<B> batchFactory)

      • getExecutorFactory

        public Supplier<ExecutorService> getExecutorFactory()

        The factory for the thread pool manager used by process(Object, Object...).

        By default this is HackedBlockingQueue.createExecutor(). Normally you shouldn't need to change this parameter, unless you want some particular execution policy.

      • setExecutorFactory

        public void setExecutorFactory(Supplier<ExecutorService> executorFactory)

      • getExecutor

        public ExecutorService getExecutor()

        This is initialised using the first time you call it, by means of getExecutorFactory(). If you invoke waitExecutor(String), in process(Object, Object...), as recommended, the internal ExecutorService returned by this is made to null again and then re-initialised by this method upon its next call.

      • waitExecutor

        protected void waitExecutor(String pleaseWaitMessage)

        Waits that all the parallel jobs submitted to the batchJob are finished. It keeps polling ExecutorService.isTerminated() and invoking ExecutorService.awaitTermination(long, TimeUnit).

        As explained above, this resets the ExecutorService that is returned by getExecutor(), so that the next time that method is invoked, it will get a new executor from getExecutorFactory().

        Parameters:
        pleaseWaitMessage - the message to be reported (via logger/INFO level) while waiting.

      • wrapBatchJob

        protected Runnable wrapBatchJob(Runnable batchJob)

        Wraps the task into some common operations. At the moment,

        • wraps exception,
        • logs the progress of completed tasks every jobLogPeriod completed tasks.
